scene-body.stagedir: Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY, FANG and his Boy with her, and SNARE following.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Master Fang, have you entered the action?

speech.speaker: FANG
speech.line: It is entered.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Where's your yeoman? Is't a lusty yeoman?
Will a' stand to 't?

speech.speaker: FANG
speech.line: Sirrah, where's Snare?

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: O Lord, ay! good Master Snare.

speech.speaker: SNARE
speech.line: Here, here.

speech.speaker: FANG
speech.line: Snare, we must arrest Sir John Falstaff.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Yea, good Master Snare; I have entered him
and all.

speech.speaker: SNARE
speech.line: It may chance cost some of us our lives, for
he will stab.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Alas the day! take heed of him; he stabbed
me in mine own house, and that most beastly: in good faith, he
cares not what mischief he does. If his weapon be
out: he will foin like any devil; he will spare neither
man, woman, nor child.

speech.speaker: FANG
speech.line: If I can close with him, I care not for his
thrust.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: No, nor I neither: I'll be at your elbow.

speech.speaker: FANG
speech.line: An I but fist him once; an a' come but
within my vice,--

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: I am undone by his going; I warrant you,
he's an infinitive thing upon my score. Good Master
Fang, hold him sure: good Master Snare, let him
not 'scape. A' comes continuantly to Pie-corner
--saving your manhoods--to buy a saddle; and he is
indited to dinner to the Lubber's-head in Lumbert
street, to Master Smooth's the silkman: I pray ye,
since my exion is entered and my case so openly
known to the world, let him be brought in to his
answer. A hundred mark is a long one for a poor lone
woman to bear: and I have borne, and borne, and
borne, and have been fubbed off, and fubbed off, and
fubbed off, from this day to that day, that it is a
shame to be thought on. There is no honesty in such
dealing; unless a woman should be made an ass and a
beast, to bear every knave's wrong.
Yonder he comes; and that errant malmsey-nose knave,
Bardolph, with him. Do your offices, do your
offices: Master Fang and Master Snare, do me, do me,
do me your offices.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: How now! whose mare's dead? what's the matter?

speech.speaker: FANG
speech.line: Sir John, I arrest you at the suit of Mistress Quickly.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Away, varlets! Draw, Bardolph: cut me off the
villain's head: throw the quean in the channel.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Throw me in the channel! I'll throw thee in the
channel. Wilt thou? wilt thou? thou bastardly
rogue! Murder, murder! Ah, thou honeysuckle
villain! wilt thou kill God's officers and the
king's? Ah, thou honey-seed rogue! thou art a
honey-seed, a man-queller, and a woman-queller.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Keep them off, Bardolph.

speech.speaker: FANG
speech.line: A rescue! a rescue!

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Good people, bring a rescue or two. Thou wo't, wo't
thou? Thou wo't, wo't ta? do, do, thou rogue! do,
thou hemp-seed!

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Away, you scullion! you rampallion! You
fustilarian! I'll tickle your catastrophe.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter the Lord Chief-Justice, and his men

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: What is the matter? keep the peace here, ho!

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Good my lord, be good to me. I beseech you, stand to me.

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: How now, Sir John! what are you brawling here?
Doth this become your place, your time and business?
You should have been well on your way to York.
Stand from him, fellow: wherefore hang'st upon him?

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: O most worshipful lord, an't please your grace, I am
a poor widow of Eastcheap, and he is arrested at my suit.

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: For what sum?

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: It is more than for some, my lord; it is for all,
all I have. He hath eaten me out of house and home;
he hath put all my substance into that fat belly of
his: but I will have some of it out again, or I
will ride thee o' nights like the mare.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: I think I am as like to ride the mare, if I have
any vantage of ground to get up.

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: How comes this, Sir John? Fie! what man of good
temper would endure this tempest of exclamation?
Are you not ashamed to enforce a poor widow to so
rough a course to come by her own?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: What is the gross sum that I owe thee?

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Marry, if thou wert an honest man, thyself and the
money too. Thou didst swear to me upon a
parcel-gilt goblet, sitting in my Dolphin-chamber,
at the round table, by a sea-coal fire, upon
Wednesday in Wheeson week, when the prince broke
thy head for liking his father to a singing-man of
Windsor, thou didst swear to me then, as I was
washing thy wound, to marry me and make me my lady
thy wife. Canst thou deny it? Did not goodwife
Keech, the butcher's wife, come in then and call me
gossip Quickly? coming in to borrow a mess of
vinegar; telling us she had a good dish of prawns;
whereby thou didst desire to eat some; whereby I
told thee they were ill for a green wound? And
didst thou not, when she was gone down stairs,
desire me to be no more so familiarity with such
poor people; saying that ere long they should call
me madam? And didst thou not kiss me and bid me
fetch thee thirty shillings? I put thee now to thy
book-oath: deny it, if thou canst.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: My lord, this is a poor mad soul; and she says up
and down the town that the eldest son is like you:
she hath been in good case, and the truth is,
poverty hath distracted her. But for these foolish
officers, I beseech you I may have redress against them.

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: Sir John, Sir John, I am well acquainted with your
manner of wrenching the true cause the false way. It
is not a confident brow, nor the throng of words
that come with such more than impudent sauciness
from you, can thrust me from a level consideration:
you have, as it appears to me, practised upon the
easy-yielding spirit of this woman, and made her
serve your uses both in purse and in person.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Yea, in truth, my lord.

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: Pray thee, peace. Pay her the debt you owe her, and
unpay the villany you have done her: the one you
may do with sterling money, and the other with
current repentance.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: My lord, I will not undergo this sneap without
reply. You call honourable boldness impudent
sauciness: if a man will make courtesy and say
nothing, he is virtuous: no, my lord, my humble
duty remembered, I will not be your suitor. I say
to you, I do desire deliverance from these officers,
being upon hasty employment in the king's affairs.

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: You speak as having power to do wrong: but answer
in the effect of your reputation, and satisfy this
poor woman.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Come hither, hostess.

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: Now, Master Gower, what news?

speech.speaker: GOWER
speech.line: The king, my lord, and Harry Prince of Wales
Are near at hand: the rest the paper tells.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: As I am a gentleman.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Faith, you said so before.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: As I am a gentleman. Come, no more words of it.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: By this heavenly ground I tread on, I must be fain
to pawn both my plate and the tapestry of my
dining-chambers.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Glasses, glasses is the only drinking: and for thy
walls, a pretty slight drollery, or the story of
the Prodigal, or the German hunting in water-work,
is worth a thousand of these bed-hangings and these
fly-bitten tapestries. Let it be ten pound, if thou
canst. Come, an 'twere not for thy humours, there's
not a better wench in England. Go, wash thy face,
and draw the action. Come, thou must not be in
this humour with me; dost not know me? come, come, I
know thou wast set on to this.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Pray thee, Sir John, let it be but twenty nobles: i'
faith, I am loath to pawn my plate, so God save me,
la!

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Let it alone; I'll make other shift: you'll be a
fool still.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Well, you shall have it, though I pawn my gown. I
hope you'll come to supper. You'll pay me all together?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Will I live?
Go, with her, with her; hook on, hook on.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Will you have Doll Tearsheet meet you at supper?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: No more words; let's have her.

scene-body.stagedir: Exeunt MISTRESS QUICKLY, BARDOLPH, Officers and Boy

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: I have heard better news.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: What's the news, my lord?

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: Where lay the king last night?

speech.speaker: GOWER
speech.line: At Basingstoke, my lord.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: I hope, my lord, all's well: what is the news, my lord?

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: Come all his forces back?

speech.speaker: GOWER
speech.line: No; fifteen hundred foot, five hundred horse,
Are marched up to my lord of Lancaster,
Against Northumberland and the Archbishop.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Comes the king back from Wales, my noble lord?

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: You shall have letters of me presently:
Come, go along with me, good Master Gower.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: My lord!

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: What's the matter?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Master Gower, shall I entreat you with me to dinner?

speech.speaker: GOWER
speech.line: I must wait upon my good lord here; I thank you,
good Sir John.

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: Sir John, you loiter here too long, being you are to
take soldiers up in counties as you go.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Will you sup with me, Master Gower?

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: What foolish master taught you these manners, Sir John?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Master Gower, if they become me not, he was a fool
that taught them me. This is the right fencing
grace, my lord; tap for tap, and so part fair.

speech.speaker: Lord Chief-Justice
speech.line: Now the Lord lighten thee! thou art a great fool.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Before God, I am exceeding weary.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Is't come to that? I had thought weariness durst not
have attached one of so high blood.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Faith, it does me; though it discolours the
complexion of my greatness to acknowledge it. Doth
it not show vilely in me to desire small beer?

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Why, a prince should not be so loosely studied as
to remember so weak a composition.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Belike then my appetite was not princely got; for,
by my troth, I do now remember the poor creature,
small beer. But, indeed, these humble
considerations make me out of love with my
greatness. What a disgrace is it to me to remember
thy name! or to know thy face to-morrow! or to
take note how many pair of silk stockings thou
hast, viz. these, and those that were thy
peach-coloured ones! or to bear the inventory of thy
shirts, as, one for superfluity, and another for
use! But that the tennis-court-keeper knows better
than I; for it is a low ebb of linen with thee when
thou keepest not racket there; as thou hast not done
a great while, because the rest of thy low
countries have made a shift to eat up thy holland:
and God knows, whether those that bawl out the ruins
of thy linen shall inherit his kingdom: but the
midwives say the children are not in the fault;
whereupon the world increases, and kindreds are
mightily strengthened.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: How ill it follows, after you have laboured so hard,
you should talk so idly! Tell me, how many good
young princes would do so, their fathers being so
sick as yours at this time is?

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Shall I tell thee one thing, Poins?

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Yes, faith; and let it be an excellent good thing.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: It shall serve among wits of no higher breeding than thine.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Go to; I stand the push of your one thing that you
will tell.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Marry, I tell thee, it is not meet that I should be
sad, now my father is sick: albeit I could tell
thee, as to one it pleases me, for fault of a
better, to call my friend, I could be sad, and sad
indeed too.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Very hardly upon such a subject.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: By this hand thou thinkest me as far in the devil's
book as thou and Falstaff for obduracy and
persistency: let the end try the man. But I tell
thee, my heart bleeds inwardly that my father is so
sick: and keeping such vile company as thou art
hath in reason taken from me all ostentation of sorrow.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: The reason?

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: What wouldst thou think of me, if I should weep?

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: I would think thee a most princely hypocrite.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: It would be every man's thought; and thou art a
blessed fellow to think as every man thinks: never
a man's thought in the world keeps the road-way
better than thine: every man would think me an
hypocrite indeed. And what accites your most
worshipful thought to think so?

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Why, because you have been so lewd and so much
engraffed to Falstaff.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: And to thee.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: By this light, I am well spoke on; I can hear it
with my own ears: the worst that they can say of
me is that I am a second brother and that I am a
proper fellow of my hands; and those two things, I
confess, I cannot help. By the mass, here comes Bardolph.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: And the boy that I gave Falstaff: a' had him from
me Christian; and look, if the fat villain have not
transformed him ape.

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: God save your grace!

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: And yours, most noble Bardolph!

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: Come, you virtuous ass, you bashful fool, must you
be blushing? wherefore blush you now? What a
maidenly man-at-arms are you become! Is't such a
matter to get a pottle-pot's maidenhead?

speech.speaker: Page
speech.line: A' calls me e'en now, my lord, through a red
lattice, and I could discern no part of his face
from the window: at last I spied his eyes, and
methought he had made two holes in the ale-wife's
new petticoat and so peeped through.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Has not the boy profited?

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: Away, you whoreson upright rabbit, away!

speech.speaker: Page
speech.line: Away, you rascally Althaea's dream, away!

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Instruct us, boy; what dream, boy?

speech.speaker: Page
speech.line: Marry, my lord, Althaea dreamed she was delivered
of a fire-brand; and therefore I call him her dream.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: A crown's worth of good interpretation: there 'tis,
boy.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: O, that this good blossom could be kept from
cankers! Well, there is sixpence to preserve thee.

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: An you do not make him hanged among you, the
gallows shall have wrong.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: And how doth thy master, Bardolph?

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: Well, my lord. He heard of your grace's coming to
town: there's a letter for you.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Delivered with good respect. And how doth the
martlemas, your master?

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: In bodily health, sir.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Marry, the immortal part needs a physician; but
that moves not him: though that be sick, it dies
not.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: I do allow this wen to be as familiar with me as my
dog; and he holds his place; for look you how be writes.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Reads 'John Falstaff, knight,'--every man must
know that, as oft as he has occasion to name
himself: even like those that are kin to the king;
for they never prick their finger but they say,
'There's some of the king's blood spilt.' 'How
comes that?' says he, that takes upon him not to
conceive. The answer is as ready as a borrower's
cap, 'I am the king's poor cousin, sir.'

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Nay, they will be kin to us, or they will fetch it
from Japhet. But to the letter.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Reads 'Sir John Falstaff, knight, to the son of
the king, nearest his father, Harry Prince of
Wales, greeting.' Why, this is a certificate.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Peace!

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Reads 'I will imitate the honourable Romans in
brevity:' he sure means brevity in breath,
short-winded. 'I commend me to thee, I commend
thee, and I leave thee. Be not too familiar with
Poins; for he misuses thy favours so much, that he
swears thou art to marry his sister Nell. Repent
at idle times as thou mayest; and so, farewell.
Thine, by yea and no, which is as much as to
say, as thou usest him, JACK FALSTAFF with my
familiars, JOHN with my brothers and sisters,
and SIR JOHN with all Europe.'
My lord, I'll steep this letter in sack and make him eat it.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: That's to make him eat twenty of his words. But do
you use me thus, Ned? must I marry your sister?

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: God send the wench no worse fortune! But I never said so.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Well, thus we play the fools with the time, and the
spirits of the wise sit in the clouds and mock us.
Is your master here in London?

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: Yea, my lord.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Where sups he? doth the old boar feed in the old frank?

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: At the old place, my lord, in Eastcheap.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: What company?

speech.speaker: Page
speech.line: Ephesians, my lord, of the old church.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Sup any women with him?

speech.speaker: Page
speech.line: None, my lord, but old Mistress Quickly and
Mistress Doll Tearsheet.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: What pagan may that be?

speech.speaker: Page
speech.line: A proper gentlewoman, sir, and a kinswoman of my master's.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Even such kin as the parish heifers are to the town
bull. Shall we steal upon them, Ned, at supper?

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: I am your shadow, my lord; I'll follow you.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Sirrah, you boy, and Bardolph, no word to your
master that I am yet come to town: there's for
your silence.

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: I have no tongue, sir.

speech.speaker: Page
speech.line: And for mine, sir, I will govern it.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Fare you well; go.
This Doll Tearsheet should be some road.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: I warrant you, as common as the way between Saint
Alban's and London.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: How might we see Falstaff bestow himself to-night
in his true colours, and not ourselves be seen?

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Put on two leathern jerkins and aprons, and wait
upon him at his table as drawers.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: From a God to a bull? a heavy decension! it was
Jove's case. From a prince to a prentice? a low
transformation! that shall be mine; for in every
thing the purpose must weigh with the folly.
Follow me, Ned.

scene.title: SCENE III. Warkworth. Before the castle.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter NORTHUMBERLAND, LADY NORTHUMBERLAND, and LADY PERCY

speech.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
speech.line: I pray thee, loving wife, and gentle daughter,
Give even way unto my rough affairs:
Put not you on the visage of the times
And be like them to Percy troublesome.

speech.speaker: LADY NORTHUMBERLAND
speech.line: I have given over, I will speak no more:
Do what you will; your wisdom be your guide.

speech.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
speech.line: Alas, sweet wife, my honour is at pawn;
And, but my going, nothing can redeem it.

speech.speaker: LADY PERCY
speech.line: O yet, for God's sake, go not to these wars!
The time was, father, that you broke your word,
When you were more endeared to it than now;
When your own Percy, when my heart's dear Harry,
Threw many a northward look to see his father
Bring up his powers; but he did long in vain.
Who then persuaded you to stay at home?
There were two honours lost, yours and your son's.
For yours, the God of heaven brighten it!
For his, it stuck upon him as the sun
In the grey vault of heaven, and by his light
Did all the chivalry of England move
To do brave acts: he was indeed the glass
Wherein the noble youth did dress themselves:
He had no legs that practised not his gait;
And speaking thick, which nature made his blemish,
Became the accents of the valiant;
For those that could speak low and tardily
Would turn their own perfection to abuse,
To seem like him: so that in speech, in gait,
In diet, in affections of delight,
In military rules, humours of blood,
He was the mark and glass, copy and book,
That fashion'd others. And him, O wondrous him!
O miracle of men! him did you leave,
Second to none, unseconded by you,
To look upon the hideous god of war
In disadvantage; to abide a field
Where nothing but the sound of Hotspur's name
Did seem defensible: so you left him.
Never, O never, do his ghost the wrong
To hold your honour more precise and nice
With others than with him! let them alone:
The marshal and the archbishop are strong:
Had my sweet Harry had but half their numbers,
To-day might I, hanging on Hotspur's neck,
Have talk'd of Monmouth's grave.

speech.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
speech.line: Beshrew your heart,
Fair daughter, you do draw my spirits from me
With new lamenting ancient oversights.
But I must go and meet with danger there,
Or it will seek me in another place
And find me worse provided.

speech.speaker: LADY NORTHUMBERLAND
speech.line: O, fly to Scotland,
Till that the nobles and the armed commons
Have of their puissance made a little taste.

speech.speaker: LADY PERCY
speech.line: If they get ground and vantage of the king,
Then join you with them, like a rib of steel,
To make strength stronger; but, for all our loves,
First let them try themselves. So did your son;
He was so suffer'd: so came I a widow;
And never shall have length of life enough
To rain upon remembrance with mine eyes,
That it may grow and sprout as high as heaven,
For recordation to my noble husband.

speech.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
speech.line: Come, come, go in with me. 'Tis with my mind
As with the tide swell'd up unto his height,
That makes a still-stand, running neither way:
Fain would I go to meet the archbishop,
But many thousand reasons hold me back.
I will resolve for Scotland: there am I,
Till time and vantage crave my company.

scene.title: SCENE IV. London. The Boar's-head Tavern in Eastcheap.

speech.speaker: First Drawer
speech.line: What the devil hast thou brought there? apple-johns?
thou knowest Sir John cannot endure an apple-john.

speech.speaker: Second Drawer
speech.line: Mass, thou sayest true. The prince once set a dish
of apple-johns before him, and told him there were
five more Sir Johns, and, putting off his hat, said
'I will now take my leave of these six dry, round,
old, withered knights.' It angered him to the
heart: but he hath forgot that.

speech.speaker: First Drawer
speech.line: Why, then, cover, and set them down: and see if
thou canst find out Sneak's noise; Mistress
Tearsheet would fain hear some music. Dispatch: the
room where they supped is too hot; they'll come in straight.

speech.speaker: Second Drawer
speech.line: Sirrah, here will be the prince and Master Poins
anon; and they will put on two of our jerkins and
aprons; and Sir John must not know of it: Bardolph
hath brought word.

speech.speaker: First Drawer
speech.line: By the mass, here will be old Utis: it will be an
excellent stratagem.

speech.speaker: Second Drawer
speech.line: I'll see if I can find out Sneak.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY and DOLL TEARSHEET

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: I' faith, sweetheart, methinks now you are in an
excellent good temperality: your pulsidge beats as
extraordinarily as heart would desire; and your
colour, I warrant you, is as red as any rose, in good
truth, la! But, i' faith, you have drunk too much
canaries; and that's a marvellous searching wine,
and it perfumes the blood ere one can say 'What's
this?' How do you now?

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: Better than I was: hem!

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Why, that's well said; a good heart's worth gold.
Lo, here comes Sir John.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Singing 'When Arthur first in court,'
--Empty the jordan.
--'And was a worthy king.' How now, Mistress Doll!

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Sick of a calm; yea, good faith.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: So is all her sect; an they be once in a calm, they are sick.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: You muddy rascal, is that all the comfort you give me?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: You make fat rascals, Mistress Doll.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: I make them! gluttony and diseases make them; I
make them not.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: If the cook help to make the gluttony, you help to
make the diseases, Doll: we catch of you, Doll, we
catch of you; grant that, my poor virtue grant that.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: Yea, joy, our chains and our jewels.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: 'Your broaches, pearls, and ouches:' for to serve
bravely is to come halting off, you know: to come
off the breach with his pike bent bravely, and to
surgery bravely; to venture upon the charged
chambers bravely,--

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: Hang yourself, you muddy conger, hang yourself!

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: By my troth, this is the old fashion; you two never
meet but you fall to some discord: you are both,
i' good truth, as rheumatic as two dry toasts; you
cannot one bear with another's confirmities. What
the good-year! one must bear, and that must be
you: you are the weaker vessel, as they say, the
emptier vessel.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: Can a weak empty vessel bear such a huge full
hogshead? there's a whole merchant's venture of
Bourdeaux stuff in him; you have not seen a hulk
better stuffed in the hold. Come, I'll be friends
with thee, Jack: thou art going to the wars; and
whether I shall ever see thee again or no, there is
nobody cares.

speech.speaker: First Drawer
speech.line: Sir, Ancient Pistol's below, and would speak with
you.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: Hang him, swaggering rascal! let him not come
hither: it is the foul-mouthed'st rogue in England.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: If he swagger, let him not come here: no, by my
faith; I must live among my neighbours: I'll no
swaggerers: I am in good name and fame with the
very best: shut the door; there comes no swaggerers
here: I have not lived all this while, to have
swaggering now: shut the door, I pray you.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Dost thou hear, hostess?

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Pray ye, pacify yourself, Sir John: there comes no
swaggerers here.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Dost thou hear? it is mine ancient.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Tilly-fally, Sir John, ne'er tell me: your ancient
swaggerer comes not in my doors. I was before Master
Tisick, the debuty, t'other day; and, as he said to
me, 'twas no longer ago than Wednesday last, 'I'
good faith, neighbour Quickly,' says he; Master
Dumbe, our minister, was by then; 'neighbour
Quickly,' says he, 'receive those that are civil;
for,' said he, 'you are in an ill name:' now a'
said so, I can tell whereupon; 'for,' says he, 'you
are an honest woman, and well thought on; therefore
take heed what guests you receive: receive,' says
he, 'no swaggering companions.' There comes none
here: you would bless you to hear what he said:
no, I'll no swaggerers.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: He's no swaggerer, hostess; a tame cheater, i'
faith; you may stroke him as gently as a puppy
greyhound: he'll not swagger with a Barbary hen, if
her feathers turn back in any show of resistance.
Call him up, drawer.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Cheater, call you him? I will bar no honest man my
house, nor no cheater: but I do not love
swaggering, by my troth; I am the worse, when one
says swagger: feel, masters, how I shake; look you,
I warrant you.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: So you do, hostess.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Do I? yea, in very truth, do I, an 'twere an aspen
leaf: I cannot abide swaggerers.

speech.speaker: PISTOL
speech.line: God save you, Sir John!

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Welcome, Ancient Pistol. Here, Pistol, I charge
you with a cup of sack: do you discharge upon mine hostess.

speech.speaker: PISTOL
speech.line: I will discharge upon her, Sir John, with two bullets.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: She is Pistol-proof, sir; you shall hardly offend
her.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Come, I'll drink no proofs nor no bullets: I'll
drink no more than will do me good, for no man's
pleasure, I.

speech.speaker: PISTOL
speech.line: Then to you, Mistress Dorothy; I will charge you.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: Charge me! I scorn you, scurvy companion. What!
you poor, base, rascally, cheating, lack-linen
mate! Away, you mouldy rogue, away! I am meat for
your master.

speech.speaker: PISTOL
speech.line: I know you, Mistress Dorothy.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: Away, you cut-purse rascal! you filthy bung, away!
by this wine, I'll thrust my knife in your mouldy
chaps, an you play the saucy cuttle with me. Away,
you bottle-ale rascal! you basket-hilt stale
juggler, you! Since when, I pray you, sir? God's
light, with two points on your shoulder? much!

speech.speaker: PISTOL
speech.line: God let me not live, but I will murder your ruff for this.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: No more, Pistol; I would not have you go off here:
discharge yourself of our company, Pistol.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: No, Good Captain Pistol; not here, sweet captain.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: Captain! thou abominable damned cheater, art thou
not ashamed to be called captain? An captains were
of my mind, they would truncheon you out, for
taking their names upon you before you have earned
them. You a captain! you slave, for what? for
tearing a poor whore's ruff in a bawdy-house? He a
captain! hang him, rogue! he lives upon mouldy
stewed prunes and dried cakes. A captain! God's
light, these villains will make the word as odious
as the word 'occupy;' which was an excellent good
word before it was ill sorted: therefore captains
had need look to 't.

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: Pray thee, go down, good ancient.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Hark thee hither, Mistress Doll.

speech.speaker: PISTOL
speech.line: Not I I tell thee what, Corporal Bardolph, I could
tear her: I'll be revenged of her.

speech.speaker: Page
speech.line: Pray thee, go down.

speech.speaker: PISTOL
speech.line: I'll see her damned first; to Pluto's damned lake,
by this hand, to the infernal deep, with Erebus and
tortures vile also. Hold hook and line, say I.
Down, down, dogs! down, faitors! Have we not
Hiren here?

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Good Captain Peesel, be quiet; 'tis very late, i'
faith: I beseek you now, aggravate your choler.

speech.speaker: PISTOL
speech.line: These be good humours, indeed! Shall pack-horses
And hollow pamper'd jades of Asia,
Which cannot go but thirty mile a-day,
Compare with Caesars, and with Cannibals,
And Trojan Greeks? nay, rather damn them with
King Cerberus; and let the welkin roar.
Shall we fall foul for toys?

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: By my troth, captain, these are very bitter words.

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: Be gone, good ancient: this will grow to abrawl anon.

speech.speaker: PISTOL
speech.line: Die men like dogs! give crowns like pins! Have we
not Heren here?

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: O' my word, captain, there's none such here. What
the good-year! do you think I would deny her? For
God's sake, be quiet.

speech.speaker: PISTOL
speech.line: Then feed, and be fat, my fair Calipolis.
Come, give's some sack.
'Si fortune me tormente, sperato me contento.'
Fear we broadsides? no, let the fiend give fire:
Give me some sack: and, sweetheart, lie thou there.
Come we to full points here; and are etceteras nothing?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Pistol, I would be quiet.

speech.speaker: PISTOL
speech.line: Sweet knight, I kiss thy neaf: what! we have seen
the seven stars.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: For God's sake, thrust him down stairs: I cannot
endure such a fustian rascal.

speech.speaker: PISTOL
speech.line: Thrust him down stairs! know we not Galloway nags?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Quoit him down, Bardolph, like a shove-groat
shilling: nay, an a' do nothing but speak nothing,
a' shall be nothing here.

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: Come, get you down stairs.

speech.speaker: PISTOL
speech.line: What! shall we have incision? shall we imbrue?
Then death rock me asleep, abridge my doleful days!
Why, then, let grievous, ghastly, gaping wounds
Untwine the Sisters Three! Come, Atropos, I say!

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Here's goodly stuff toward!

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Give me my rapier, boy.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: I pray thee, Jack, I pray thee, do not draw.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Get you down stairs.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Here's a goodly tumult! I'll forswear keeping
house, afore I'll be in these tirrits and frights.
So; murder, I warrant now. Alas, alas! put up
your naked weapons, put up your naked weapons.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: I pray thee, Jack, be quiet; the rascal's gone.
Ah, you whoreson little valiant villain, you!

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: He you not hurt i' the groin? methought a' made a
shrewd thrust at your belly.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Have you turned him out o' doors?

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: Yea, sir. The rascal's drunk: you have hurt him,
sir, i' the shoulder.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: A rascal! to brave me!

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: Ah, you sweet little rogue, you! alas, poor ape,
how thou sweatest! come, let me wipe thy face;
come on, you whoreson chops: ah, rogue! i'faith, I
love thee: thou art as valorous as Hector of Troy,
worth five of Agamemnon, and ten times better than
the Nine Worthies: ah, villain!

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: A rascally slave! I will toss the rogue in a blanket.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: Do, an thou darest for thy heart: an thou dost,
I'll canvass thee between a pair of sheets.

speech.speaker: Page
speech.line: The music is come, sir.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Let them play. Play, sirs. Sit on my knee, Doll.
A rascal bragging slave! the rogue fled from me
like quicksilver.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: I' faith, and thou followedst him like a church.
Thou whoreson little tidy Bartholomew boar-pig,
when wilt thou leave fighting o' days and foining
o' nights, and begin to patch up thine old body for heaven?

scene-body.stagedir: Enter, behind, PRINCE HENRY and POINS, disguised

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Peace, good Doll! do not speak like a death's-head;
do not bid me remember mine end.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: Sirrah, what humour's the prince of?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: A good shallow young fellow: a' would have made a
good pantler, a' would ha' chipp'd bread well.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: They say Poins has a good wit.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: He a good wit? hang him, baboon! his wit's as thick
as Tewksbury mustard; there's no more conceit in him
than is in a mallet.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: Why does the prince love him so, then?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Because their legs are both of a bigness, and a'
plays at quoits well, and eats conger and fennel,
and drinks off candles' ends for flap-dragons, and
rides the wild-mare with the boys, and jumps upon
joined-stools, and swears with a good grace, and
wears his boots very smooth, like unto the sign of
the leg, and breeds no bate with telling of discreet
stories; and such other gambol faculties a' has,
that show a weak mind and an able body, for the
which the prince admits him: for the prince himself
is such another; the weight of a hair will turn the
scales between their avoirdupois.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Would not this nave of a wheel have his ears cut off?

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Let's beat him before his whore.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Look, whether the withered elder hath not his poll
clawed like a parrot.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Is it not strange that desire should so many years
outlive performance?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Kiss me, Doll.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Saturn and Venus this year in conjunction! what
says the almanac to that?

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: And look, whether the fiery Trigon, his man, be not
lisping to his master's old tables, his note-book,
his counsel-keeper.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Thou dost give me flattering busses.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: By my troth, I kiss thee with a most constant heart.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: I am old, I am old.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: I love thee better than I love e'er a scurvy young
boy of them all.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: What stuff wilt have a kirtle of? I shall receive
money o' Thursday: shalt have a cap to-morrow. A
merry song, come: it grows late; we'll to bed.
Thou'lt forget me when I am gone.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: By my troth, thou'lt set me a-weeping, an thou
sayest so: prove that ever I dress myself handsome
till thy return: well, harken at the end.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Some sack, Francis.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
POINS
speech.line: Anon, anon, sir.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Ha! a bastard son of the king's? And art not thou
Poins his brother?

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Why, thou globe of sinful continents! what a life
dost thou lead!

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: A better than thou: I am a gentleman; thou art a drawer.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Very true, sir; and I come to draw you out by the ears.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: O, the Lord preserve thy good grace! by my troth,
welcome to London. Now, the Lord bless that sweet
face of thine! O, Jesu, are you come from Wales?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Thou whoreson mad compound of majesty, by this light
flesh and corrupt blood, thou art welcome.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: How, you fat fool! I scorn you.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: My lord, he will drive you out of your revenge and
turn all to a merriment, if you take not the heat.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: You whoreson candle-mine, you, how vilely did you
speak of me even now before this honest, virtuous,
civil gentlewoman!

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: God's blessing of your good heart! and so she is,
by my troth.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Didst thou hear me?

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Yea, and you knew me, as you did when you ran away
by Gad's-hill: you knew I was at your back, and
spoke it on purpose to try my patience.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: No, no, no; not so; I did not think thou wast within hearing.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: I shall drive you then to confess the wilful abuse;
and then I know how to handle you.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: No abuse, Hal, o' mine honour, no abuse.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Not to dispraise me, and call me pantier and
bread-chipper and I know not what?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: No abuse, Hal.

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: No abuse?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: No abuse, Ned, i' the world; honest Ned, none. I
dispraised him before the wicked, that the wicked
might not fall in love with him; in which doing, I
have done the part of a careful friend and a true
subject, and thy father is to give me thanks for it.
No abuse, Hal: none, Ned, none: no, faith, boys, none.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: See now, whether pure fear and entire cowardice doth
not make thee wrong this virtuous gentlewoman to
close with us? is she of the wicked? is thine
hostess here of the wicked? or is thy boy of the
wicked? or honest Bardolph, whose zeal burns in his
nose, of the wicked?

speech.speaker: POINS
speech.line: Answer, thou dead elm, answer.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: The fiend hath pricked down Bardolph irrecoverable;
and his face is Lucifer's privy-kitchen, where he
doth nothing but roast malt-worms. For the boy,
there is a good angel about him; but the devil
outbids him too.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: For the women?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: For one of them, she is in hell already, and burns
poor souls. For the other, I owe her money, and
whether she be damned for that, I know not.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: No, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: No, I think thou art not; I think thou art quit for
that. Marry, there is another indictment upon thee,
for suffering flesh to be eaten in thy house,
contrary to the law; for the which I think thou wilt howl.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: All victuallers do so; what's a joint of mutton or
two in a whole Lent?

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: You, gentlewoman,-

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: What says your grace?

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: His grace says that which his flesh rebels against.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Who knocks so loud at door? Look to the door there, Francis.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: Peto, how now! what news?

speech.speaker: PETO
speech.line: The king your father is at Westminster:
And there are twenty weak and wearied posts
Come from the north: and, as I came along,
I met and overtook a dozen captains,
Bare-headed, sweating, knocking at the taverns,
And asking every one for Sir John Falstaff.

speech.speaker: PRINCE HENRY
speech.line: By heaven, Poins, I feel me much to blame,
So idly to profane the precious time,
When tempest of commotion, like the south
Borne with black vapour, doth begin to melt
And drop upon our bare unarmed heads.
Give me my sword and cloak. Falstaff, good night.

scene-body.stagedir: Exeunt PRINCE HENRY, POINS, PETO and BARDOLPH

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Now comes in the sweetest morsel of the night, and
we must hence and leave it unpicked.
More knocking at the door!
How now! what's the matter?

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: You must away to court, sir, presently;
A dozen captains stay at door for you.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: To the Page Pay the musicians, sirrah. Farewell,
hostess; farewell, Doll. You see, my good wenches,
how men of merit are sought after: the undeserver
may sleep, when the man of action is called on.
Farewell good wenches: if I be not sent away post,
I will see you again ere I go.

speech.speaker: DOLL TEARSHEET
speech.line: I cannot speak; if my heart be not read to burst,--
well, sweet Jack, have a care of thyself.

speech.speaker: FALSTAFF
speech.line: Farewell, farewell.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: Well, fare thee well: I have known thee these
twenty-nine years, come peascod-time; but an
honester and truer-hearted man,--well, fare thee well.

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: Within Mistress Tearsheet!

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: What's the matter?

speech.speaker: BARDOLPH
speech.line: Within Good Mistress Tearsheet, come to my master.

speech.speaker: MISTRESS QUICKLY
speech.line: O, run, Doll, run; run, good Doll: come.
Yea, will you come, Doll?
